title: Chudakaran: Why We Shave a Child's Head
excerpt: Of all the childhood Samskaras, Chudakaran â€” the first haircut â€” is perhaps the one that draws the most curious questions from young parents. Why do we shave an infant's head? What are we letting go of? The answers go deeper than you might expect.

body.heading: Hair Carried From Another Life
body.text: The Vedic understanding of Chudakaran begins with a belief that the hair a child is born with carries the karmic impressions of their past life â€” the desires, attachments, and impurities of a soul that has traveled long before arriving in this family. By removing this hair in the first or third year of life, the family offers the child a clean slate. The Paraskara Grihyasutra, which codifies this ceremony, calls it a ritual of purification: the shaving of the janma-jata-kesh (birth-hair) followed by the growing of fresh hair, symbolizing new beginnings in this lifetime. What looks like a simple haircut is, in its original understanding, an act of spiritual rebirth.

body.heading: The Ceremony Itself
body.text: Chudakaran is typically performed in the first, third, or fifth year of the child's life â€” odd years are considered auspicious â€” and ideally before the age of seven. Many families perform it at a sacred river, a temple, or a family home. The barber, who in this context is considered a participant in the ceremony (not merely a service provider), shaves the head while the pandit recites mantras. The hair is not simply thrown away. It is carried reverently to a sacred river or buried in the earth â€” returned, essentially, to nature. In some traditions, a single lock called the Shikha is left at the crown, which remains uncut for life and is considered the seat of spiritual energy.

body.heading: Tirupati's Echo
body.text: If you have ever stood in the long queues at Tirupati Balaji and seen the enormous halls where devotees offer their hair â€” tonnes of it collected daily, auctioned internationally for wigs and hair extensions â€” you are witnessing the same impulse at a massive scale. The hair offering at Tirupati is called tonsure, and it carries the identical symbolism: I surrender my vanity, my attachment to appearance, my ego. I come before the divine with nothing to offer but myself, stripped of adornment. When a parent brings their toddler for Chudakaran, they are performing the same act of surrender â€” not on behalf of their ego, but of all that the child carried before this life.

body.heading: The Science Behind the Tradition
body.text: What strikes many modern parents is that Ayurveda offers a parallel reasoning. The skull of a newborn is not fully ossified â€” the fontanelle (Brahmarandhra in Sanskrit, literally "the opening of Brahma") remains soft for months. Ayurvedic physicians note that the shaving of the head at this stage allows the skull to cool properly, improves blood circulation to the scalp, and encourages thicker, stronger hair growth. The new hair that grows after Chudakaran is often noticeably different in texture and volume â€” coarser, fuller. Whether you approach it through the Vedic or the physiological lens, the result is the same: renewal.

body.heading: What the Child Does Not Know
body.text: Every parent who has held a squirming, bewildered toddler through a Mundan knows one thing: the child has no idea what is happening. They may cry. They may grab the razor. They will certainly be confused. And yet, something quiet happens in that room â€” in the parents. To offer your child's very first hair, the hair they came into the world with, to the river or the earth â€” it is an act of humility that few rituals match. It says: this child does not belong to us. They belong to the divine. We are only caretakers. For the length of one barber's careful strokes, that truth is held fully.
